items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Robert Ball, Bond Program Manager - SGI Construction Management
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action Regarding the Selection/Appointment of Measures G, E, and I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Members
	 
Pursuant to Section 15278 of the Education Code, the District is obligated to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) in order to satisfy the accountability requirements of Proposition 39 type general obligation bonds. The Committee is required to consist of a minimum of seven (7) members appointed by the Board of Trustees. 
	 
As explained in the terms of Proposition 39, the CBOC is required to have members that meet the criteria listed below:
One (1) member shall be active in a business organization representing the business community located within the District
One (1) member shall be active in a senior citizens’ organization
One (1) member shall be active in a bona fide taxpayers’ organization
One (1) member shall be the parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the district
One (1) member shall be both a parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the District and be active in a parent-teacher organization, such as the Parent-Teacher Association or the School Site Council
Two (2) members of the community at-large
No employees or officials of the District can be appointed to the CBOC.  Also vendors, contractors, or consultants of the District are not allowed to serve as members of the Committee. The District requires members to have residency in the District, and strives for geographical diversity across the District.
	 
Under the current bylaws of the CBOC, members are allowed to serve three (3) consecutive two (2) year terms. To allow for history and consistency, terms are staggered to avoid all members terming out at the same time.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action on Charter Petition for Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School
	 
Brief Introduction and Summary of Recommendation
On April 1, 2014, Will Eden, Entrepreneur in Residence, Alpha Public Schools, submitted a petition (“Petition”) dated March 27, 2014, to establish the Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School, a ninth through twelfth grade high school with a projected enrollment of 607 students, in the Alum Rock community of the East Side Union High School District. The Petition was received by the Board of Trustees on April 17, 2014. 
	 
California Education Code § 47605 (b) requires that “no later than 30 days after receiving a petition… the governing board of the school district shall hold a public hearing on the provision of the charter at which time the governing board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district, and parents.”  The Education Code further requires that the “governing board of the school district shall either grant or deny the charter within 60 days of receipt of the petition.” The date for the governing board’s decision “may be extended by an additional 30 days if both parties agree to the extension.” The June 19th regularly scheduled meeting of the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees (Board) occurs four days after the 60-day deadline.  Alpha Public Schools agreed to a four-day extension for the Board’s decision. 
	 
The Board held a public hearing on the Alpha: Cindy Avitia Charter Petition on May 15, 2014, at 7:00 p.m. during the Regular Board Meeting. The petitioner, Will Eden, spoke on behalf of the charter school. Pursuant to Section 47605, the Board, following review of the Petition and public hearing, shall either grant or deny the charter petition. The Board will make a decision about whether to grant or deny the Petition at its meeting on June 19, 2014.  
	 
The mission of the charter school as stated in the petition on p. 14 is: “to provide children from high-poverty communities an education that effectively develops the academic skills and competencies of character to overcome the achievement gap, graduate from college, and become self-reliant and productive leaders.” To achieve that mission, the charter school proposes to: “provide the rigor, structure, and support needed to guide students to academic success.  Alpha will provide an excellent educational program that rests on best practices, quality professional development, and an instructional framework that allows for a strong match between learning needs and teaching methods through differentiation ”(p. 14). 
Standards for Review/Denial/Authorization
Education Code section 47605 establishes the requirements a petitioner must satisfy in order for his petition for the charter school to be approved.  Education Code section 47605 (b) provides that  the governing board of a school district shall not deny a petition for the establishment of a charter school unless it makes written factual findings, specific to the particular petition, setting forth specific facts to support one of more of the following findings:
The charter school presents an unsound educational program for the pupils to be enrolled in the charter school.
The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition.
The petition does not contain the number of parent or teacher signatures required by Education Code section 47605 (A)-(B).
The petition does not contain an affirmation that the charter school “shall be nonsectarian in its programs, admission policies, employment practices, and all other operations, shall not charge tuition, and shall not discriminate against any pupil on the  basis” pursuant to [Education Code] Section 220 of “disability, gender, nationality, race or ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or any other characteristic that is contained in the definition of hate crimes set forth in Section 422.55 of the Penal Code in any program or activity conducted by an educational institution that receives, or benefits from state financial assistance….”
The petition does not contain reasonably comprehensive descriptions of all of the following:
(i) A description of the educational program of the school, designed, among other things, to identify those whom the school is attempting to education, what it means to be an “educated person” in the 21st century, and how learning best occurs. The goals identified in that program shall include the objective of enabling pupils to become self-motivated, competent, and lifelong learners.
(ii) If the proposed school will served high school pupils, a description of the manner in which the charter school will inform parents about the transferability of courses to other public high schools and the eligibility of courses to meet college entrance requirements. Courses offered by the charter school that are accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges may be considered transferable and courses approved by the University of California or the California State University as creditable under the “A” to “G” admissions criteria may be considered to meet college entrance requirements.
The measurable pupil outcomes identified for use by the charter school.  
The method by which pupil progress in meeting those pupil outcomes is to be measured.
The governance structure of the school including, but not limited to, the process to be followed by the school to ensure parental involvement.
 The qualifications to be met by individuals to be employed by the school.
 The procedures that the school will follow to ensure the health and safety of pupils and staff. These procedures shall include the requirement that each employee of the school furnish the school with a criminal record summary as described in Section 44237.
The means by which the school will achieve a racial and ethnic balance among its pupils that is reflective of the general population residing within the territorial jurisdiction of the school district to which the charter petition is submitted.
Admission requirements, if applicable.
The manner in which annual, independent financial audits shall be conducted, which shall employ generally accepted accounting principles, and the manner in which audit exceptions and deficiencies shall be resolved to the satisfaction of the chartering authority.
The procedures by which pupils can be suspended or expelled.
The manner by which staff members of the charter schools will be covered by the State Teachers’ Retirement System, the Public Employees’ Retirement System, or federal social security.
The public school attendance alternatives for pupils residing within the school district who choose not to attend charter schools.
 A description of the rights of any employee of the school district upon leaving the employment of the school district to work in a charter school, and of any rights of return to the school district after employment at a charter school.
The procedures to be followed by the charter school and the entity granting the charter to resolve disputes relating to provision of the charter.
A declaration whether or not the charter school shall be deemed the exclusive public school employer of the charter school for purposes of the Educational Employment Relations Act. 
A description of the procedures to be used if the charter school closes. The procedures shall ensure a final audit of the school to determine the disposition of all assets and liabilities of the charter school, including plans for disposing of any net assets and for the maintenance and transfer of pupil records.  
Review of the Petition 
Staff reviewed the Petition for Alpha: Cindy Avitia Charter School utilizing the criteria for charter approval set forth in the California Educational Code Section 47605.  Staff’s assessment of the information provided in the Petition with respect to each of the criterion in Education Code Section 47605 is set forth below and on the attached East Side Union High School District Staff Charter School Review Matrix.  Page number references are to the Alpha: Cindy Avitia Charter Petition provided to the East Side Union High School District on April 1, 2014, and received by the Board on April 17, 2014. 
	 
Required Signatures
A charter petition must be signed by either (1) a number of parents/guardians equivalent to at least one-half of the number of students that the charter school estimates will enroll in the charter school for its first year of operation; or (2) a number of teachers equivalent to at least one-half the number of teachers that the charter school estimates will be employed at the school during its first year of operation.  Education Code section 47605 (l) provides that
	[t]eachers in charter school shall be required to hold a Commission on Teacher Credentialing certificate, permit, or other document equivalent to that which a teacher in other public school would be required to hold…. It is the intent of the Legislature that charter schools be given flexibility with regard to noncore, noncollege preparatory courses.’
	 
The Petition was signed by 184 parents or legal guardians, who by signing the Petition “certify that they are meaningfully interested in having [their] child or ward attend the charter school….” Staff concludes that the Petition contains the required number of parent signatures.
	 
Required Elements and Findings in Accordance with Education Code Section 47605(b)
Educational Program   
       Staff finds that the Petition contains a sufficient description of the educational program.
	 
Ability to Successfully Implement the  Program Set Forth in the Petition
Staff finds no facts to demonstrate the petitioner is unlikely to successfully implement the program.
	 
Required Parent or Teacher Signatures
       Staff finds that this requirement was met.
	 
Required Affirmations
       Staff finds that the petition contains all of the required affirmations.
	 
Comprehensive Descriptions
Staff finds that the petition contains a reasonably comprehensive description of all required elements, except the following:
Description of the Educational Program listed in the section above at A (i)
Staff finds that the Petition contains insufficient information regarding:
English Language Arts
The scope and sequence for the 9th and 10th grade Common Core English Language Arts State Standards
The rationale for placement of students in either a traditional or an advanced placement English course
Social Studies/World Languages/Electives
Information regarding how the California Common Core State Standards for Literacy in History/ Social Science will be incorporated into social science instruction
Mathematics
The Common Core Mathematics State Standards and the eight Mathematical Practice Standards
A plan to offer Advanced Placement Calculus and Non-Advanced Placement Calculus that would not negatively affect students who enroll in the Non-Advanced Placement courses based on the UC Doorways practices
Science
The Next Generation Science Standards and the incorporation of the California Common Core State Standards for Literacy in Science
Core Courses
Core cores defined by Education Code under the UC A-G requirements and No Child Left Behind (NCLB)
English Language Learners
Alternative assessments for the reclassification of English Language Learners during the interim period when the California Standards Tests (CSTs) are no longer available for use
Expected Instructional Materials
Instructional  materials need to be updated to include the Common Core State Standards across the curriculum
Measureable Pupil Outcomes listed in the section above at B:
Physical Fitness Testing, required by law (Education Code section 60800) for ninth graders
Misidentification of the California High School Exit Exam (CAHSEE) as an instrument to measure college readiness
Planned use of the Partnership for Assessment of  Readiness for College and Careers (PARCC) Assessment rather than the Smarter Balanced Assessment which supports the California Assessment of Student Performance and Progress (CAASPP)
Graduation Requirements listed in the section above as (ii):
Clear delineation of graduation requirements, course units and the total units needed for graduation
A plan for Special Education students who experience difficulty in meeting the rigorous graduation standards
Graduation requirements that far exceed those of most high schools that potentially could disadvantage students who chose to attend Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School by not awarding a diploma
Service Credit listed in the section above at M:
Clarification regarding whether staff will continue to earn service credit (tenure) in the district while employed at the charter school
Closure Procedures listed in the section above at P:
The closure procedure information was incomplete.
Financial Plan
Staff determined that the financial plan is sufficient and requested to have clarified, the source of the revenue for uniforms listed under local revenue
Administration’s Recommended Conditions of Approval
The District Administration recognizes that the Alpha’s stated mission is achievable and, if successfully implemented, would serve an important need and provide an important benefit to the community.  Alpha Public Schools has operated Alpha: Blanca Alvarado Middle School in the Alum Rock community for two years. In its first year of operation, Alpha: Blanca Alvarado Middle School earned “an API of 828 as a school. This included a Latino API of 814” (p. 9).  
	 
On May 7, 2014, the District Charter Review Team visited Alpha: Blanca Alvarado Middle School to learn more about the curricular model. They visited classrooms to observe the instructional program, met with parents, teachers, administration, Alpha Board members and students.  Subsequent to the Alpha: Blanca Alvarado Middle School site visit, on May 27, 2014, the District Charter Review Team held a meeting with Alpha petitioners to review deficiencies in the charter petition, answer clarifying questions and  discuss the revisions needed to meet the conditions stated below. The District Charter Review Team is committed to working with the petitioners to ensure a satisfactory charter petition.
	 
Notwithstanding Alpha Public Schools’ work at the middle school, the District Administration has concerns about the broad descriptions of the education program, presented in the charter petition that do not adequately convey an understanding of the Common Core State Standards in several curricula areas. For the aforementioned and proceeding reasons described in detail in Section III above, the Administration recommends conditionally approving the Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School charter with the conditions stated in this memo.
	 
Condition #1:  Petition Deficiencies 
	 
Correct the deficiencies in the charter petition noted in the East Side Union High School District Charter School Review Matrix evaluation, submitted to the Board during these authorization proceedings, by no later than September 25, 2014. The deficiencies are delineated above in Section III.
	 
Condition #2: Memorandum of Understanding
	 
Alpha Public Schools must successfully negotiate an acceptable Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) agreement with the District no later than September 25, 2014.     
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION: 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and consider the proposed Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School charter petition submitted by Petitioner, Will Eden, Alpha Public Schools. If the Board determines to authorize the charter conditionally based on the satisfactory submission and resolution of the conditions stated above by the dates indicated above, then Administration proposes and recommends that the Board adopt the above analysis and factual findings in support of its conditional approval.  On that basis, Administration recommends authorizing the charter petition based on satisfaction of Conditions 1-2 above as described herein and that the Petition be approved solely on that basis for a term of 5 years, commencing on July 1, 2015, to end on June 30, 2020. It is further recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the District administration to sign off on the conditions of approval for the Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School charter petition once the petitioners have satisfactorily met the specified conditions.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and consider the proposed Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School charter petition submitted by Petitioner, Will Eden, Alpha Public Schools. If the Board determines to authorize the charter conditionally based on the satisfactory submission and resolution of the conditions stated above by the dates indicated above, then Administration proposes and recommends that the Board adopt the above analysis and factual findings in support of its conditional approval. On that basis, Administration recommends authorizing the charter petition based on satisfaction of Conditions 1-2 above as described herein and that the Petition be approved solely on that basis for a term of 5 years, commencing on July 1, 2015, to end on June 30, 2020. It is further recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the District administration to sign off on the conditions of approval for the Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School charter petition once the petitioners have satisfactorily met the specified conditions.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.02
	 
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-29 Increase of School Developer Fees
	 
The Mitigation Fee Act of 1986 (Govt. Code 66000 et seq.), updated by the Leroy F. Green School Facilities Act of 1998 (Ed. Code 17620), permits school districts to charge developers a fee for new construction and reconstruction on residential, commercial and industrial projects.  These fees are commonly referred to as developer fees.  Biannually, the State increases the amount of fees schools can levy based on a revised State formula.  In January 2014, the State Allocation Board approved an increase that adjusted the developer fees for commercial and industrial to $0.54, and for residential to $3.36 per square foot.
	 
In order to increase the fee it levies upon development, the District must document that an increase is warranted, publish a notice of public hearing, hold a public hearing, adopt a resolution regarding school facility/developer fees, and notify the City of San Jose and Santa Clara County of the adopted resolution.
	 
Attached is Board Resolution #2013/2014-29 that sets forth the continued justification that would permit the District to collect developer fees up to the maximum allowed by law.  In addition, attached is the Developer Fee Study dated June 2014, which justifies collection of the increased fee.  The Study documents an analysis of existing facilities inventory, existing student capacity, enrollment projections, construction costs, average high school size and average new home size.
	 
The District entered into an Agreement with its feeder districts on January 22, 1987, to allocate 33.33% of allowable developer fees to East Side Union High School District and 66.66% to feeder school districts.  As such, with the Board’s adoption of Resolution #2013/2014-29, the District’s developer fee levy would be modified as follows and would become effective August 19, 2014:

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve The NHU Foundation's Request for Material Revision to the Latino College Preparatory Academy Charter Petition
	 
Brief Introduction and Summary of Recommendation
On March 24, 2011, the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees (Board) approved the charter renewal petition for Latino College Preparatory Academy (LCPA), granting The NHU Foundation permission to operate LCPA within the boundaries of the East Side Union High School District, located in San Jose, California. The Board granted The NHU Foundation for LCPA, a term of five years, from July 1, 2011 to June 30, 2016. This was the second renewal for LCPA which was first approved by the Board on January 29, 2001. The East Side Union High School District (District) received the charter renewal petition on December 31, 2010, and held a public hearing on February 17, 2011. 
	 
On June 4, 2014, the East Side Union High School District received a letter (Attachment A) from The NHU Foundation informing the District of its intention to move LCPA from its current location on the Mount Pleasant District campus at 1966 Flint Avenue, San Jose, California, to the National Hispanic University, located at 14271 Story Road, San Jose, California. The change in location constitutes a material change to the charter petition and is consistent with a request for a material revision. From its inception or founding to June 30, 2011, The NHU Foundation operated LCPA on the National Hispanic University campus in buildings separate from the National Hispanic University. The NHU Foundation has operated LCPA on the Mount Pleasant site since July 2011.  
	 
During a monitoring visit to the LCPA campus in May, ESUHSD staff was notified informally, regarding the NHU Foundation’s plan to return to the National Hispanic University campus effective July 1, 2014. Furthermore, NHU staff informed District staff that at minimum, two other tenants, Santa Clara University and National Hispanic University, will occupy and conduct their programs, in various portions of the same building in which The NHU Foundation plans to house LCPA. NHU staff have made clear to ESUHSD staff that Santa Clara University’s use of the facility will be limited to evenings and National Hispanic University’s remaining students’ involvement will be mainly online. Attachment B contains a schematic that illustrates how and where NHU plans to allocate space for LCPA.  
	 
District staff visited the proposed school site at National Hispanic University and have found it to be satisfactory or adequate for a school of approximately 400 students and will service their program. 
	 
Current Location of LCPA
	 
The location of the school facility is referenced on page 31 of the Latino College Preparatory Academy Charter Renewal Petition submitted to the East Side Union High School District on January 1, 2011, and approved on March 24, 2011 (Attachment C).
	 
The school has been located at 14271 Story Road since it was founded.  Due to the short term remaining on its lease and the deteriorating condition of the present campus, the school must now relocate. For this purpose the Foundation has leased a school site from the Mt. Pleasant School District, located approximately 10 minutes from its current campus. The Foundations Charter School Committee and staff will work with faculty and parents to accomplish a successful transition. The scheduled date for the move is July 1, 2011.
	 
Proposed Change to the Location of LCPA
	 
The NHU Foundation proposes to move LCPA to the National Hispanic University facility located at 14271 Story Road, San Jose, California (Attachment D). 
	 
In order to give Latino College Preparatory Academy (LCPA) a permanent home, the school administration and Charter School Committee are working to move the campus from Ida Jew Academies in Mt. Pleasant Elementary School District to its original home at 14271 Story Road for the 2014-2015 academic year. All stakeholders will be engaged in the facilities move process and the NHU Foundation will be supporting the school staff with the resources at its disposal.  The move will occur over the course of the summer of 2014. 
Standard for Review/Denial Authorization
Pursuant to Education Code § 47607 (a) (1), the Board must consider whether to approve the material revision. Education Code § 47607 (a) (2) requires that “material revisions of charters” are to “be governed by the standards and criteria in Section 47605.” Therefore, if the Board should decide to deny NHU’s material revision request for LCPA, then the Board must make “written factual findings,” specific to the particular petition, setting forth specific facts to support one or more of the following findings: 
The charter school presents an unsound educational program for the pupils to be enrolled in the charter school.
The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition.
The petition does not contain the number of signatures required by subdivision (a).
The petition does not contain an affirmation of each of the conditions described in subdivision (d). 
The petition does not contain reasonably comprehensive descriptions of all of the required elements.
Findings #1, #3, #4 and #5 would not be applicable.  If the Board decides to deny the request to relocate LCPA from its current site on the Mt. Pleasant Elementary School campus to National Hispanic University, it must make “written factual findings” with respect to Finding #2.  However, staff found that the facility LCPA will occupy and will allow the NHU Foundation to implement the program specified in the LCPA charter petition.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The Administration recommends that the Board approve the material revision request to the Latino College Preparatory charter petition to permit The NHU Foundation to change the location of the school effective July 1, 2014.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding First Amendment to Employment Contract for Senior Manager of Internal Controls
	 
	 
At the June 5, 2014, Board Meeting, the Board approved a 1.95% increase to the base salary of the Senior Manager of Internal Controls (Kelly Kwong), effective July 1, 2014, consistent with the salary increases granted to other District employees.  The Board further directed the preparation of an amendment to Ms. Kwong’s contract to reflect the salary adjustment.
	 
The amendment as presented reflects the adjustment of Ms. Kwong’s base salary by the approved 1.95%.  In addition, the amendment includes the following addition to Ms. Kwong’s contract:
	 
“During the term of this AGREEMENT, the SENIOR MANAGER’s base salary shall be increased prospectively by the same percentage salary increase that may be granted by the BOARD OF TRUSTEES to the DISTRICT’s management personnel in any given school year.”
	 
Previously, the contract base salary adjustments were limited to increases in cost-of-living allowances (COLA) granted to all District management personnel.  This proposed change and amended language is consistent with all other District contract administrative/management personnel.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
1.95% of original base salary of Senior Manager of Internal Controls
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Unrestricted General Fund and Restricted Funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration and Legal Counsel recommend that the Board approve the First Amendment to the Employment Contract of the Senior Manager of internal Controls as presented.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  11.06
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Board Members’ Compensation/Adjustments to 
Compensation per Education Code §35120
		 
		 
The calculation of Board Members’ monthly compensation is governed by Education Code section 35120.  Currently, Board Members’ monthly stipend as allowed by law is $420.00.  On June 27, 2013, the Board took action to reduce its monthly compensation from $750.00 to the current $420.00. 
		 
Education Code section 35120(e) provides:
		 
“On an annual basis, the governing board may increase the compensation of individual board members beyond the limits delineated in this section, in an amount not to exceed 5 percent based on the present monthly rate of compensation. Any increase made pursuant to this section shall be effective upon approval by the governing board.”
		 
A search of District records reveals that, notwithstanding section 35120(e), the Board has not implemented the statutorily allowed 5% increase in the last fifteen years, except once in June 2013.  Administration recommends that the Board approve a 5% increase to the Board Member compensation to take effect July 1, 2014, resulting in a new monthly compensation per Board Member of $441.00 pursuant to Education Code section 35120(e).
		 
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Twenty-one dollars ($21.00) more per Board Member in monthly compensation
                                                                                              
FUNDING SOURCE:
Unrestricted General Fund
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board approve a 5% increase in Board Member monthly compensation to $441 per month, effective July 1, 2014, pursuant to Education Code section 35120(e).
​

Attached for adoption by the Board of Trustees is Resolution #2013/2014-30 regarding Frank Fiscalini.  The Resolution recognizes Frank Fiscalini for his many achievements and humble devotion to the betterment of the East Side Community and his leadership and contributions to San Jose and the Santa Clara Valley.

 EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
BOARD OF TRUSTEES
RESOLUTION #2013/14-30
	 
Frank Fiscalini
	 
WHEREAS, Frank Fiscalini first served as a teacher at James Lick High School in 1950 and then served as Superintendent of the East Side Union High School District from 1956 to 1982;
	 
WHEREAS, during Frank Fiscalini’s tenure as Superintendent, he had the privilege of putting the District together with the building of Andrew P. Hill, Wm. C. Overfelt, Mt. Pleasant, Piedmont Hills, Oak Grove, Silver Creek, Foothill, Yerba Buena, Santa Teresa, and Independence High Schools, including his last major construction project, which was the District Office;
	 
WHEREAS, Frank Fiscalini served as San Jose City Council Member (1992-2000) and Vice Mayor (1998-2000) and is currently serving as a volunteer with several non-profit agencies;
	 
WHEREAS, Frank Fiscalini’s community service include coordination of the Saint Joseph Cathedral Restoration Project for the Diocese of San Jose, founding Board Member for Opera San Jose, Board Member for FACES Silicon Valley 
(40 years); Board Member for Little Italy San Jose, and CEO of Alexian Brothers Hospital;
	 
WHEREAS, Frank Fiscalini has dedicated his life to the service of youth;
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, the Members of the Board of the East Side Union High School District do hereby recognize Frank Fiscalini, “A True Renaissance Man,” for his many contributions to San Jose and the Santa Clara Valley.  He is recognized for his many achievements and humble devotion to the betterment of the East Side Community.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Local Control Accountability Plan (LCAP)
	 
The text below was taken directly from the State approved LCAP template.
	 
The Local Control Accountability Plan (LCAP) and annual update template shall be used to provide details regarding local educational agencies’ (LEAs) actions and expenditures to support pupil outcomes and overall performance pursuant to Education Code sections 52060, 52066, 47605, 47605.5, and 47606.5. 
	 
For school districts, pursuant to Education Code section 52060, the LCAP must describe, for the school district and each school within the district, goals and specific actions to achieve those goals for all pupils and each subgroup of pupils identified in Education Code section 52052, including pupils with disabilities, for each of the state priorities and any locally identified priorities.
	 
The LCAP is intended to be a comprehensive planning tool. LEAs may reference and describe actions and expenditures in other plans and funded by a variety of other fund sources when detailing goals, actions, and expenditures related to the state and local priorities. LCAPs must be consistent with school plans submitted pursuant to Education Code section 64001. The information contained in the LCAP, or annual update, may be supplemented by information contained in other plans (including the LEA plan pursuant to Section 1112 of Subpart 1 of Part A of Title I of Public Law 107-110) that are incorporated or referenced as relevant in this document.  
	 
For each section of the template, LEAs should comply with instructions and use the guiding questions as prompts (but not limits) for completing the information as required by statute. 
	 
State Priorities
The State priorities listed in Education Code sections 52060 and 52066 can be categorized as specified below for planning purposes, however, school districts and county offices of education must address each of the state priorities in their LCAP.
	 
A. Conditions of Learning: 
	 
Basic: degree to which teachers are appropriately assigned pursuant to Education Code section 44258.9, and fully credentialed in the subject areas and for the pupils they are teaching; pupils have access to standards-aligned instructional materials pursuant to Education Code section 60119; and school facilities are maintained in good repair pursuant to Education Code section 17002(d). (Priority 1)
	 
Implementation of State Standards: implementation of academic content and performance standards adopted by the state board for all pupils, including English learners. (Priority 2)
	 
Course access: pupil enrollment in a broad course of study that includes all of the subject areas described in Education Code section 51210 and subdivisions (a) to (i), inclusive, of Section 51220, as applicable. (Priority 7)
	 
Expelled pupils (for county offices of education only): coordination of instruction of expelled pupils pursuant to Education Code section 48926.  (Priority 9)
	 
Foster youth (for county offices of education only): coordination of services, including working with the county child welfare agency to share information, responding to the needs of the juvenile court system, and ensuring transfer of health and education records.  (Priority 10)
	 
B. Pupil Outcomes: 
	 
Pupil achievement: performance on standardized tests, score on Academic Performance Index, share of pupils that are college and career ready, share of English learners that become English proficient, English learner reclassification rate, share of pupils that pass Advanced Placement exams with 3 or higher, share of pupils determined prepared for college by the Early Assessment Program. (Priority 4)
	 
Other pupil outcomes: pupil outcomes in the subject areas described in Education Code section 51210 and subdivisions (a) to (i), inclusive, of Education Code section 51220, as applicable. (Priority 8)   
	 
C. Engagement: 
	 
Parent involvement: efforts to seek parent input in decision making, promotion of parent participation in programs for unduplicated pupils and special need subgroups.  (Priority 3)
	 
Pupil engagement: school attendance rates, chronic absenteeism rates, middle school dropout rates, high school dropout rates, high school graduations rates. (Priority 5)
	 
School climate: pupil suspension rates, pupil expulsion rates, other local measures including surveys of pupils, parents and teachers on the sense of safety and school connectedness. (Priority 6)
	 
In addition to the strategic planning engagement stakeholder and focus group meetings, the district has had many community engagement meetings to specially discuss the LCFF and LCAP.  The following are the dates of the community engagement meetings:
	 
March, 2014
School Site Council/ELAC
DAC/DELAC - March 18th
African-American Student Advocates - March 13th
Vietnamese Parents - March 15th
Latino Parents - March 16th
Board of Trustees -  March 20th
April, 2014

Migrant Education - April 11th
May, 2014
Update to the Board on the community input (Board Student Session/Meeting) - May 6th
First Public Hearing (Board Meeting) - May 15th
June, 2014
Board of Trustees Approval (Board Meeting) - June 19th
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Local Accountability Plan (LCAP).

SUBJECT:

The East Side Adult Education Program offers 60 English as a Second Language courses for our community members wishing to learn to read, write, and speak English.  The courses are offered in three strands: Beginning level, Intermediate level and High/Advanced level.
	 
Classes are offered at three main campuses, three high school, two libraries, and one community center during the morning, afternoon, and evening.  Classes are selected and offered based on need and student availability.  The current level of ESL support are:
	 
Andrew Hill High School

                                                 One high/advanced level

Afternoon Classes:                  One multi-level beginning

Evening Classes:                     Seven beginning level

                                                 One high/advanced level
                                                 One citizenship
	 
CBET classes are all multi-level beginning classes and are at Independence, Mt. Pleasant, and Yerba Buena High Schools.
	 
Additional classes at the beginning level are offered at the Alum Rock and Tully Community Libraries and one at the Grail Family Services Center.

Item: 13.01
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:  
						 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt the Annual Budget for Fiscal Year 2014-15
		 
The 2014-15 Annual Budget reflects the actions and input of the Governing Board, Superintendent, stakeholders, and staff to develop a budget that is responsive to District needs and priorities.  The final budget was prepared taking into account all changes relative to the Governor’s May Revision proposal. The Governor's May Revision State Teachers Retirement System (STRS) recommendation and re-calibration of the Local Control Funding Formula (LCFF) Gap percentages represent a loss of over $11 million in revenues.  The loss of revenues come at a time when the District is trying to implement the Local Control Accountability Plan (LCAP) and restore critical services and programs.  The District will revisit these items once the final State budget is adopted to determine short and long-term implications for budgetary planning. 
		 
The District may consider submitting a 45-day budget revision to the adopted budget depending upon the results of the State’s final budget adoption actions.  The District will still need to be vigilant in managing deficit spending and will need to closely monitor future spending to ensure spending is balanced. The District will continue to closely monitor and report on the State’s budget circumstances and how it impacts the District as information becomes available.         
		 
The 2014-15 budget indicates that the District is recommending that a positive budget be adopted based on the District’s ability to maintain sufficient reserves for the upcoming and two subsequent fiscal years. The attached budget book with executive summary provides a more detailed analysis of the fiscal year 2014-15 District budget and required State Standardized Account Code Structure (SACS) Reporting Forms.  
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the annual budget for fiscal year 2014-15 with a positive certification for the 2014-15 fiscal year and two subsequent years.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
				 
Item:  13.04
				 
TO:
Board of Trustees
								 
FROM:  
								 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
							 
							 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Karen Poon, Director of Finance, and Kelly Kwong, Senior Manager of Internal Controls
							 
							 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Authorize School Connected Organizations to Solicit Contributions or Funds per Education Code 51520 and 51521
				 
				 
A School Connected Organization (“SCO”) is a separately organized and controlled non-profit entity that raises funds for student programs.  SCOs are frequently organized and known as “booster” clubs and parent/teacher/student associations.  The School Connected Organizations are not controlled by or overseen by the District.  The law requires, however, that the School Connected Organizations must obtain the District’s approval to solicit funds on the District school sites for the benefit of students, or if it solicits funds on the representation that the money received is to be used in whole or in part for the benefit of students or any other District school or students.
				 
Education Code section 51520(a) provides: 
“During school hours, and within one hour before the time of opening and within one hour after the time of closing of school, pupils of the public school shall not be solicited on school premises by teachers or others to subscribe or contribute to the funds of, to become members of, or to work for, any organization not directly under the control of the school authorities, unless the organization is a nonpartisan, charitable organization organized for charitable purposes by an act of Congress or under the laws of the state, the purpose of the solicitation is nonpartisan and charitable, and the solicitation has been approved by the county board of education or by the governing board of the school district in which the school is located.” (Emphasis added.)
				 
Education Code section 51521 further provides in part: 
“No person shall solicit any other person to contribute to any fund or to purchase any item of personal property, upon the representation that the money received is to be used wholly or in part for the benefit of any public school or the student body of any public school, unless such person obtains the prior written approval of either the governing board of the school district in which such solicitation is to be made or the governing board of the school district having jurisdiction over the school or student body represented to be benefited by such solicitation, or the designee of either of such boards.”
				 
In addition, Board Policy 1230 School Connected Organizations states, “Persons proposing to establish a school-connected organization shall submit a request to the Governing Board for authorization to operate at the school… Requests for subsequent authorization shall be presented to the Superintendent or designee annually…” 
				 
After a review of the School Connected Organization’s financials and other criteria, the Administration recommends that the Board authorize the following School Connect Organizations to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for the benefit of any District students or academic or athletic programs:
Evergreen Valley High School Athletic Booster Club (EVHSABC)
Evergreen Valley High School Band Boosters
Evergreen Valley High School PTSA (Parent Teacher Student Association)
Independence High School 76th Cavalry Band Boosters Club
James Lick High School Athletic Booster Club (JLHSABC)
Mt. Pleasant High School Booster Club 
Oak Grove High School PCO (Parent Community Organization)
Piedmont Hills High School Parent Booster Club
Pirate Football Boosters, Inc.
Silver Creek Athletic Booster Club (SCABC)
Silver Creek High PTSA (Parent Teacher Student Association)
Santa Teresa Athletic Boosters Club (STABC)
Santa Teresa Music and Arts Association Inc. (STMAA)
Santa Teresa Organization of Parents and Staff Inc. (STOPS)
WCO Booster Club (for W. C. Overfelt High School)
				 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
				 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
				 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the SCOs listed above pursuant to Education Code 51520(a) to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for nonpartisan and charitable purposes for the benefit of District students, academic or athletic programs.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for the Successor Contract: From East Side Union High School District to the San Jose Federation of Teachers, Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the San Jose Federation of Teachers, Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO for the 2014-2015 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 2014-2015 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; and contract language amendments to Article 9000, 15000, 18000 and Appendix A.  The District also has an interest in ensuring that contract language is consistent with the current funding formulas; eliminating references to COLA.  The District seeks a three year agreement.

Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated

Administration recommends that the Board adopt the District’s initial proposal for successor contract to the San Jose Federation of Teachers, Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO for the 2014-2015 school year.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Award a Lease Leaseback Preconstruction Agreement for Independence High School Building B and Campus Site Improvement Projects
	 
On May 15, 2014, the Board of Trustees awarded McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., a Lease Leaseback Preconstruction Services Agreement for the Independence High School Performing Arts Center Building F Modernization project.  Per the language of the RFQ/P-15-13-14, if the District was satisfied with the performance of the developer, Administration could ask for a proposal to perform the remaining scopes of work for the Independence High School Campus Modernization.  Also, at the May 15, 2014, Board meeting, staff informed the Board that it was their intent to bring back a recommendation to award a second Pre-Construction Agreement to McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., at the June 19, 2014, Board meeting for approval for the additional scopes of work.
	 
McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., is proposing to provide preconstruction services for Building B and Campus Site Improvements that include the following scopes: estimating services at the schematic design (SD); design development (DD); and construction documents (CD), and stages of design for both projects; value analysis and constructability review to insure that the project is on budget; and development of the final Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for both projects, similar to the Building F project.  Additionally, the developer will also provide an estimate to rebuild Building B to its original layout due to the fire to provide evidence necessary for the District’s insurance claim.
           
Once the District receives the GMP, District Administration will bring forth to the Board a recommendation to award Lease Leaseback Site Lease and Facilities Lease Agreements.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:                                                    
Not to Exceed $80,320
                       
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Obligation Bond Measure E & I
	 
RECOMMENDATION:       
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees award a Lease Leaseback Preconstruction Services Agreement with McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., for Independence High School Building B and Campus Site Improvements projects in an amount not to exceed $80,320.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Qualify Architectural Firms
	 
	 
In November 2000, California Proposition 35, also known as the Public Works Projects Act of 2000, was approved by California voters. The Act requires public entities like East Side Union High School District to qualify architectural firms prior to retaining them for professional services.  The District requires architectural firms to meet the following criteria:
	 
California licensing or registry (for architects and engineers)
Successful experience with the Division of the State Architect
Successful experience on educational projects, particularly K-12
Successful experience in projects similar to the District’s renovation and new construction projects
Record of responsiveness
Acceptable business practices, such as discipline coordination, cost estimating, cost management, quality control, project team communications, dispute resolution, etc.
Resumes of key personnel
Litigation history
Competitive fee schedule
	 
Background:
The District released a Request for Qualifications for Architectural Services on December 19, 2013 (RFQ-08-13-14). 
	 
Nineteen (19) Statements of Qualification (SOQ) were received on January 24, 2014. Based on the evaluation and at the March 20, 2014, Board meeting, the Board of Trustees approved staff’s recommendation to approve all nineteen firms to be added to the existing pool of architects for the construction program.  
	 
It is in the District’s best interest to allow interested architectural firms to join the pool over time and to actively expand the pool to also include firms who provide design services in engineering disciplines (structural, mechanical, electrical, civil, etc.), as well as other types of professional service providers whose services are critical to a successful construction program (e.g., commissioning).  Administration will bring forth to the Board of Trustees on a quarterly basis (as needed) recommendations to add qualified professional service providers to the pool.
	 
Administration has received two (2) Statements of Qualifications (SOQ) to be included in the pool of architects.  The design firms are Sally Swanson Architects, Inc., and Dreiling Terrones Architecture, Inc. (DTA).  The firm's SOQ’s went through the screening process.  Both firms' scores qualified them to be included in the pool.
	 
	 
Fiscal Impact:
Not Applicable
	 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the additions of Sally Swanson Architects, Inc., and Dreiling Terrones Architecture, Inc., (DTA) to the pool of firms qualified to provide architectural services.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Takeover Agreement to Complete the Piedmont Hills High School New Auxiliary Gymnasium Project 
	 
On April 21, 2011, the Board took action to award a contract for the construction of the Piedmont Hills High School New Auxiliary Gymnasium BCI Builders, Inc. ("BCI") in the original contract amount of $3,860,000.00.  In connection with the contract, BCI posted a Performance Bond in favor of the District for the full contract amount.  The surety under the performance bond is The Guaranty Company of North America USA.
	 
A Notice to Proceed was issued by the District to BCI on May 5, 2011.  At the time, the total contract time was estimated to be 425 calendar days with an estimated completion date of July 7, 2012.  BCI fell substantially behind schedule and encountered other performance issues did not complete the work within the contract period.  On August 23, 2012, the District’s Governing Board took unanimous action to delegate authority to District Administration the authority and power to terminate the Contract and/or Contractor's right to perform the Work of the Contract and to serve written notice upon BCI and its Surety of the District's termination of the Contract and/or Contractor's right to perform the Work of the Contract in accordance with the terms of the Contract, with such notice containing the grounds of termination and such other grounds as Administration may determine after further investigation.
	 
As of this date there remains substantial punch list work to be performed on the project.
	 
On June 6, 2014, the District issued the required notice to BCI and its surety terminating BCI’s rights to perform the work of the contract in accordance with the contract documents for the Project.  BCI’s time to cure pursuant to the contract documents has expired.
	 
Surety GCNA has agreed to enter into a Takeover Agreement with the District whereby GCNA  take over and perform the remaining work required under the contract documents with another licensed contractor under the terms of the original Performance Bond.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
                                                                                               
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration and Legal Counsel recommend that the Board authorize and delegate to the Superintendent and Associate Superintendent of Business Services the authority to enter into a Takeover Agreement for the completion of the Piedmont Hills High School New Auxiliary Gymnasium and the closeout of the subject contract.
items.item_recommendation: Administration and Legal Counsel recommend that the Board authorize and delegate to the Superintendent and Associate Superintendent of Business Services the authority to enter into a Takeover Agreement for the completion of the Piedmont Hills High School New Auxiliary Gymnasium and the closeout of the subject contract.

SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION: 
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
	 
				A
				B
				C
				D
				E
				F
				G
				H
				I
				J
				K
				L
				M
				N
				O
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  17.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Application for Title I School Wide Program for Calero High School
	 
A school wide program is a comprehensive reform strategy designed to upgrade the entire educational program in a Title I school; its primary goal is to ensure that all students, particularly those who are low-achieving, demonstrate proficient and advanced levels of achievement on State academic achievement standards.
	 
In general, a Title I school may operate as a school wide program only if a minimum of 40 percent of the students in the school, or residing in the attendance area served by the school, are from low-income families. [Section 1114(a)(1) of Title I of ESEA].
	 
Whereas Title I targeted assistance programs only provide educational services to identified individual students, school wide programs allow staff in schools with high concentrations of students from low-income families  to redesign their entire educational program to serve all students. The emphasis in school wide program schools is on serving all students, improving all structures that support student learning, and combining all resources, as allowed, to achieve a common goal. School wide programs maximize the impact of Title I. Adopting this strategy should result in an ongoing, comprehensive plan for school improvement that is owned by the entire school community and tailored to its unique needs.  
	 
Calero High School Qualifies for School Wide Program Status based on all required elements:
	 
A school operating a school wide program must conduct a comprehensive needs assessment that identifies the school's strengths and challenges in key areas that affect student achievement [Section 1114(b) (1) (A) Title I of ESEA].
The school must develop a comprehensive school wide plan that describes how it will achieve the goals it has identified as a result of its needs assessment [Section 1114(b)(I)(B-J) and 34 CFR 200.27) of Title I of ESEA].  The school wide plan must:
Identify reform strategies, aligned with the needs assessment, that are research based and provide opportunities for all children to meet the State's proficient or advanced level of academic achievement
Provide instruction by highly qualified teachers
Offer high quality, ongoing professional development
Create strategies to attract highly qualified teachers
Create strategies to increase parental involvement
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the application for Title I School Wide Program for Calero High School.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
					 
Item:  20.01
					 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
								 
								 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
								 
								 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Ratification of Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services At or Below $50,000   
					 
					 
The attached lists the Bond/Capital Projects Contracts for Professional Services at or below $50,000 being recommended for Board ratification. 
					 
Fiscal Impact:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Funding Source:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services at or below $50,000 as recommended in the attachment and Authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.
